content: this it s up to you if you have a lot of 4ply fingering or sock yarn to use up you can substitute 1 strand of dk with 2 strands of 4ply you will need to allow more yarn than the bare minimum to get a nice balance of colours i recommend that you pick one pair of colours for the trims around the body and cuffs as this will tie everything in together and look good i also suggest that you try and match the sleeves and the right and left fronts so they are symmetrical but only if you want to page2 of 9 copyright © kate harvie all rights reserved for personal use only 13 august 2024 gauge 14sts and 22 row to 10cm/4 inches over stocking/stockinette stitch which i achieved on 6mm needles stitch gauge is more important than row gauge note that if you are using assorted yarns that dk yarns do vary a bit in thickness it doesn t matter if your gauge is a bit wobbly but the more similar your yarns are the more consistent your gauge will be needles and notions circular needle of size needed to achieve gauge i used 6mm us 10 the length you will need will depend on the size of sweater you are making for the smallest sizes a 40cm 16 inch needle might be long enough but you will need a 60cm 24 inch or 80cm 32 inch needle for the larger sizes circular needle of same length but 1mm smaller i used 5mm us 8 spare needle for working 3-needle bind-off in same size as your larger needle or one size larger if you tend to bind off too tightly circular needles of your choice in both sizes for working smaller circumferences dpns short circular or magic loop stitch marker for marking start and end of round two safety pins for holding sts at underarms stitch holder or waste yarn for holding sts at centre front tapestry needle for sewing in ends page3 of 9 copyright © kate harvie all rights
